H0.text: It gave spacecraft a timed trajectory, allowing NASA to conserve fuel when manned space exploration began and enabling spacecraft to successfully travel and return to Earth.

H1.text: It ensured spacecraft would return home safely was the explanation for why NASA’s gravity‑assist concept was useful for spacecraft to successfully travel and return to Earth when manned space exploration began, as it helped conserve fuel.

H2.text: It was helpful in planning spacecraft trajectories, enabling NASA to conserve fuel when manned space exploration began and allowing spacecraft to successfully travel and return to Earth.

H3.text: It ensured spacecraft would avoid being pulled into the sun, allowing NASA to conserve fuel when it first used gravity‑assist maneuvers during the early days of manned space exploration.

A4.text: Gravity assist maneuvers can greatly change the speed of a spacecraft without expending propellant, and can save significant amounts of propellant, so they are a useful technique to save fuel.

A5.text: Methods of speed and direction change that do not require fuel to be burned are advantageous, because they allow extra maneuvering capability and course enhancement, without spending fuel from the limited amount which has been carried into space.

A6.text: The flyby of Jupiter, used as a gravity assist, allowed the craft to reach Pluto at high velocity without the complications of slowing down.

A7.text: Flybys modify the direction of the probe and adds to its heliocentric velocity.

A8.text: The Voyager program launched in 1977, conducting flybys of Jupiter and Saturn, Neptune, and Uranus on a trajectory to leave the Solar System.

A9.text: The Space Shuttle was criticized for not being as reusable and cost-effective as advertised.
